issues.title: Should we add ciphersuites with pure PQ KEM + signatures?
issues.author: rohanmahy

pulls.title: Update for IETF 122
pulls.author: bifurcation
pulls.body:
* Refresh references, including new combiner drafts
* Include a more fulsome collection of algorithm options

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body: Created this issue: https://github.com/cfrg/draft-irtf-cfrg-hybrid-kems/issues/8

I don't think these MLS combos make sense, and the AFAIK the names are wrong

- There is no reason to use SHA512 for everything. Only the P521 and Ed448 MLS ciphersuites currently use SHA512. 
- Align the security levels and pick a matching HASH and AEAD (see exception ††)
- Likewise, for the ciphersuites that use already need SHA3 in their KDF, maybe we should use SHA3 as the MLS ciphersuite HASH function?
- Since AES192 is often available and AES256 is quite fast, use AES256 even when using the 192 security level (like MLS ciphersuite 0x0007 does, which actually only has 192 bits of security).
- (††) CSNA 2.0 sort of deprecated SHA256 even for the 128 bit security level; people who want to use pure PQ are almost certainly following CSNA and therefore probably need SHA384.

MLS_128_X-Wing_AES128GCM_SHA256_Ed25519
MLS_128_QSF-KEM(ML-KEM-768,P-256)-XOF(SHAKE256)-KDF(SHA3-256)_AES128GCM_SHA3-256_P256
MLS_192_QSF-KEM(ML-KEM-1024,P-384)-XOF(SHAKE256)-KDF(SHA3-256)_AES256GCM_SHA3-384_P384
MLS_128_ML-KEM-768_AES128GCM_SHA384_P256 (††)
MLS_192_ML-KEM-1024_AES256GCM_SHA384_P384

reviews.author: rohanmahy
reviews.body: We need to agree on what hashes and aeads go with which KEMs

comments.body: symmetric algorithms are generally consider not practically vulnerable to PQ atttack. Maybe just delete the sentence there?

```suggestion
encryption, hash, and signature algorithms with the same target security level.
```

There is an adopted MLS WG item that is also related to ML-KEM, but doesn't define any ciphersuites.

```suggestion
abbrev: MLS Cipher Suites with ML-KEM
```

```suggestion
The values `TBDH0` and `TBDH1` refer to the code points to be assigned by IANA for
```

```suggestion
* `TBDH0 = QSF-KEM(ML-KEM-768,P-256)-XOF(SHAKE256)-KDF(SHA3-256)`
* `TBDH1 = QSF-KEM(ML-KEM-1024,P-384)-XOF(SHAKE256)-KDF(SHA3-256)`
```
@dconnolly , do you have an opinion of SHA3 vs SHA2 for the MLS ciphersuite hash function for anyone doing QFS?

* The thinking on AES-256 and SHA-512 was motivated by the "double the key/hash size" approach to PQ for symmetric.
* I don't have as strong feeling about SHA2 vs. SHA3
    * On the one hand, yes, folks will have SHA3 for other reasons in some cases
    * On the other hand, CNSA 2.0 still lists SHA2 as "General Purpose" and SHA3 as "In Specific Applications"
    * In any case, CNSA 2.0 does forbid the 256-bit hash length
* Using the full QSF expansions seems really unwieldy, and unnecessary because these are just mnemonics; the specific algorithms are detailed below.
* This is just an initial stab, we can debate in the WG

Counter-offer: 

```
MLS_128_X_Wing_AES256GCM_SHA512_Ed25519
MLS_128_QSF_MLKEM768_P256_AES256GCM_SHA3_512_P256
MLS_192_QSF-MLKEM768_P256_AES256GCM_SHA3_512_P384
MLS_128_MLKEM768_AES128GCM_SHA512_P256
MLS_192_MLKEM1024_AES256GCM_SHA512_P384
```
Disagree.  For example, CNSA 2.0 forbids AES-128.

```suggestion
encryption, hash, and signature algorithms.
```
Disagree.  Can't use ML-KEM without a ciphersuite.

I don't have a strong feeling here, but I think a lot of readers will see ML-KEM in this way and assume this is the entire MLS PQ strategy. I would spell it out to avoid confusion, not because what you wrote is inaccurate.

```suggestion
| 0xTBD1 | 0x647a  | 0x0002 | 0x0002 | SHA384 | ed25519                |
| 0xTBD2 | 0xTBDH0 | 0x0002 | 0x0002 | SHA384 | ecdsa_secp256r1_sha256 |
| 0xTBD3 | 0xTBDH1 | 0x0002 | 0x0002 | SHA384 | ecdsa_secp384r1_sha384 |
| 0xTBD4 | 0x0041  | 0x0002 | 0x0002 | SHA384 | ecdsa_secp256r1_sha256 |
| 0xTBD5 | 0x0042  | 0x0002 | 0x0002 | SHA384 | ecdsa_secp384r1_sha384 |
```

```suggestion
| TBD1 | MLS_128_X_Wing_AES256GCM_SHA384_Ed25519    |  Y  | [RFCXXXX] |
| TBD2 | MLS_128_QSF-KEM(ML-KEM-768,P-256)-0xTBDH0_AES256GCM_SHA384_P256      |  Y  | [RFCXXXX] |
| TBD3 | MLS_192_QSF-KEM(ML-KEM-1024,P-384)-0xTBDH1_AES256GCM_SHA384_P384     |  Y  | [RFCXXXX] |
| TBD4 | MLS_128_ML_KEM_768_AES256GCM_SHA384_P256   |  Y  | [RFCXXXX] |
| TBD5 | MLS_192_ML_KEM_1024_AES256GCM_SHA384_P384  |  Y  | [RFCXXXX] |

> Note to IANA, please replace `THDH0` and `TBDH1` in lines 2 and 3 of the table.
```
ok, AES256 with the CNSA consistency and Grover's

> @dconnolly , do you have an opinion of SHA3 vs SHA2 for the MLS ciphersuite hash function for anyone doing QFS?

SHA3 is a secure KDF, SHA2 used on its own outside of HKDF is not

> @dconnolly , do you have an opinion of SHA3 vs SHA2 for the MLS ciphersuite hash function for anyone doing QFS?

Oh I have to look up again how the MLS ciphersuite uses its parameterized hash function outside of the hybrid KEM context, which needs a secure KDF

> > @dconnolly , do you have an opinion of SHA3 vs SHA2 for the MLS ciphersuite hash function for anyone doing QFS?
> 
> Oh I have to look up again how the MLS ciphersuite uses its parameterized hash function outside of the hybrid KEM context, which needs a secure KDF

@dconnolly 
MLS uses SHA256/384/512 in all currently-registered ciphersuites for generating KeyPackageRefs, ProposalRefs, membership_tag, confirmation_hash, tree_hash, etc.

MLS use key derivation extensively in the Key Schedule.
Each existing MLS ciphersuite has an **_implicit_** HPKE KDF algorithm as shown in [RFC 9420 Table 7](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9420.html#table-7). The only IANA registrations currently are HKDF-SHA256/384/512. This is clearly **NOT**  what we want for the combiners and for plain ML-KEM. For one thing the key length is wrong if we use anything except HKDF-SHA256, and all the ML-KEM implementations will have a SHAKE library somewhere. I don't understand the combiners well enough to understand if you can just IANA register SHAKE256 as an HPKE KDF, or if all three algorithm documents (XWing, irtf-cfrg-hybrid-kems, connolly-cfrg-hpke-mlkem) should also be IANA registering one or more HPKE KDFs that are particular for their key derivation procedures.

OK, I think draft-irtf-cfrg-hybrid-kems needs to IANA register both `KDF(SHA3-256)` (referencing Section 6.1 of FIPS202(, and `XOF(SHAKE256)` (referencing Section 6.2 of FIPS202) in the IANA HPKE KDF registry. Anyone?

> > > @dconnolly , do you have an opinion of SHA3 vs SHA2 for the MLS ciphersuite hash function for anyone doing QFS?
> > 
> > 
> > Oh I have to look up again how the MLS ciphersuite uses its parameterized hash function outside of the hybrid KEM context, which needs a secure KDF
> 
> @dconnolly MLS uses SHA256/384/512 in all currently-registered ciphersuites for generating KeyPackageRefs, ProposalRefs, membership_tag, confirmation_hash, tree_hash, etc.
> 
> MLS use key derivation extensively in the Key Schedule. Each existing MLS ciphersuite has an **_implicit_** HPKE KDF algorithm as shown in [RFC 9420 Table 7](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9420.html#table-7). The only IANA registrations currently are HKDF-SHA256/384/512. This is clearly **NOT** what we want for the combiners and for plain ML-KEM. For one thing the key length is wrong if we use anything except HKDF-SHA256, and all the ML-KEM implementations will have a SHAKE library somewhere. I don't understand the combiners well enough to understand if you can just IANA register SHAKE256 as an HPKE KDF, or if all three algorithm documents (XWing, irtf-cfrg-hybrid-kems, connolly-cfrg-hpke-mlkem) should also be IANA registering one or more HPKE KDFs that are particular for their key derivation procedures.

pulls.title: Add pure PQ ciphersuites with PQ sigs
pulls.author: rohanmahy

comments.body:
```suggestion
| TBD6 | MLS_128_ML-KEM-768_AES256GCM_SHA384_ML-DSA-65  |  Y  | RFCXXXX |
```

```suggestion
| 0xTBD6 | 0x0041  | 0x0011 | 0x0002 | SHA384 | mldsa65                |
```

```suggestion
The first five ciphersuites defined in this document combine a post-quantum (or PQ/T hybrid) KEM with a traditional signature algorithm. As such, they are designed to provide confidentiality against quantum and classical attacks, but provide authenticity against classical attacks only.  Thus, these cipher suites do not provide full post-quantum security, only post-quantum confidentiality.

The last two cipher suites also use post-quantum signature algorithms.
```

```suggestion
The signature schemes for ML-DSA-65 and ML-DSA-87 {{MLDSA}} are defined in {{!I-D.ietf-tls-mldsa}}.
```
